page.title: 02Landscape of Herm.
page.content: Although Herm is a small island the landscape varies greatly from north to south. The north end of the island is a low grassy common,close-cropped by rabbits, unique in the Channel Islands because it is composed of wind blown shell sand which favours lime loving plants. It is ringed by sand dunes and beautiful sandy beaches, Shell beach being the most notable. The dunes protect the common and marram grass has been planted to prevent erosion. In the centre of the island the land rises to a plateau of gently rolling farmland, with some small woods. In the south are steep cliffs, with a cliff path which continues all round the island.
